awd_titl_txt: CSBR: Natural History: Critical Curation for a Critical Collection: The Schuster Herbarium at The Field Museum
awd_abstract_narration:
Natural history specimen collections in museums and academic institutions document species diversity and provide essential information for broad applications ranging from conservation, securing national resources, discovery of new species, to agriculture and medicine. Collections are also an important resource for education and outreach. The Field Museum herbarium houses almost 3 million dried plant and fungi specimens. In 2013, the Museum acquired 35,000 liverwort specimens from the private herbarium of one of the most preeminent botanists of the 20th century. Liverworts are a small group of land plants that are closely related to the more familiar mosses. They play a critical role in our understanding of plant evolution and are ecologically significant. This recent acquisition makes The Field Museum liverwort collection, of over 220,000 specimens, the largest collection in the US and among the top four in the world. The recently acquired liverwort collection is in critical need of curation because of its poor condition. There is vital type material, used to describe and name new species, requiring urgent attention. This project will ensure the preservation of this collection as a national resource for future generations. The project also engages teens in understanding the role collections play in furthering scientific discovery. Families, students, and the general public can also participate as Citizen Scientists and help discover biodiversity by visiting http://microplants.fieldmuseum.org. The project has strong training, outreach and educational components that will improve science instruction and student learning, leveraging museum resources.

The principal objective is to curate the recently acquired private herbarium of an estimated 35,000 liverwort (Marchantiophyta) specimens of the late Prof. Rudolf M. Schuster, one of the most preeminent bryologists in the history of the discipline. The current condition of this collection, ranging from specimens in original newspaper and brown paper bags to original collecting packets, necessitates extensive curation. The bryology research community has been waiting decades to access this important collection in its entirety as many significant specimens remained in private residence and were not made available. There is vital type material that requires urgent attention. The principal objectives include curating, barcoding, databasing and imaging all label data and selected specimens.  The timing of these collection improvement activities will leverage and is synergistic with national digitization efforts and international research programs. The digitization effort will provide digital access to this collection, unlock new distribution records and new species to science, and contribute to international databasing activities such as GBIF, The Plant List, and EOL.  All data resulting from this project will be shared with iDigBio (https://www.idigbio.org/), ensuring accessibility to researchers and educators.  Duplicate specimen material will be distributed to countries of origin that would provide valuable reference material, mainly from under-resourced yet biodiversity rich regions.

por.por_cntn:
Natural history specimen collections in museums and academic institutions document species diversity and provide essential information for broad applications ranging from conservation, securing national resources, discovery of new species, to agriculture and medicine. Collections are also an important resource for education and outreach. The Field Museum herbarium houses almost 3 million dried plant and fungi specimens. In 2013, the Museum acquired over 50,000 liverwort specimens from the private herbarium of one of the most preeminent botanists of the 20th century. Liverworts are a small group of land plants that are closely related to the more familiar mosses. They play a critical role in our understanding of plant evolution and are ecologically significant. This recent acquisition makes The Field Museum liverwort collection, of over 220,000 specimens, the largest collection in the US and among the top four in the world. The recently acquired liverwort collection was in critical need of curation because of its poor condition. This project ensured the preservation of this collection as a national resource for future generations. The project also engaged teens in understanding the role collections play in furthering scientific discovery. Families, students, and the general public also participated as Citizen Scientists.

The condition of this collection prior to this project, ranged from specimens in original newspaper and brown paper bags to original collecting packets, necessitating extensive curation. The entire collection has now been inventoried in detail, sorted by country and taxonomically, bar-coded, organized, and re-packeted where necessary, so that the collections are now entirely accessible and can be searched. There are a total of 58,974 specimens from 31 regions or countries that can now be searched and utilized by the research community, which has been waiting decades to access this important collection in its entirety as many significant specimens remained in private residence and were not made available. Vital type material was discovered (material used to describe new species to science). The principal objectives included curating, barcoding, databasing and imaging all label data and selected specimens. The digitization effort coupled with taxonomic expertise who provided identifications to collections that hitherto had never been identified or examined, many collected over six decades ago, have already unlocked new distribution records and new species to science, and contribute to international databasing activities. Duplicate specimen material is also being actively  distributed to countries of origin that would provide valuable reference material, mainly from under-resourced yet biodiversity rich regions.

Some key accomplishments during this project have included:

  • The entire collection has been inventoried in detail, sorted by country and taxonomically, organized, re-packeted where necessary, so that the collections are now entirely accessible and can be searched. There are a total of 58,974 specimens from 31 regions or countries that can now be searched and utilized.

  • Over 20,000 specimens transferred from non-archival to archival packets. This included specimens in brown paper bags, disintegrated packets, and about 14,000 specimens in their original newspaper. All vital material that was inappropriately housed is now completed.

  • Over 18,800 specimens are fully databased, imaged, barcoded and publicly accessible. Over 12,500 specimens have been partially databased.

  • All 1,024 types from packets and microscopic slides have been databased and cross-referenced verifying type status. Many of these had never been accessible before.

  • Some 7,465 specimens remain in packets and brown paper bags and are being evaluated for scientific importance, most of these lack sufficient label data, some lack data entirely, but are undergoing a final asssement before being discarded.

  • Inventoried R. M. Schuster's illustrative plates.

  • We are aware of at least seven publications that have benefited directly from activities related to this project during the project period.

  • Active increase in loans and visitors; seven visiting scientists working on the Schuster collection during the project period.

  • Actively used by researchers as part of the Flora of North America project as well as flora projects elsewhere, e.g., Flora of New Zealand.

  • In arrangement with 13 institutions/individuals that have expressed interest in gift for determination, or repatriating duplicates to country of origin.

  • Participated in the 2017 Specimens! This was a public exhibit showcasing Field Museum's natural history collections. This included an exhibit piece devoted to R. M. Schuster and a kiosk devoted to MicroPlants - a new Citizen Scientist initiative.

  • Supported many interns and students throughout the project period.

  • Participated in a number of outreach activities, including WeDigBio and a recently formed Collections Club - an army of weekend volunteers who significantly helped curate 1000's of specimens from newspaper to archival packets.

  • Received significant media coverage with newspaper, online news media and television.
